script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I have to start with something that’s been haunting me as I studied this week. In Moses 1:12, Satan confronts Moses and says, ‘Moses, son of man, worship me.’ Why does Satan use that specific phrase, ‘son of man,’ when just moments earlier God called Moses ‘my son’ in verse 4? What’s behind this subtle but chilling shift in language?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, that’s a fantastic question, and it cuts right to the heart of a profound spiritual battle. Satan’s choice of words isn’t accidental—it’s a deliberate attempt to strip Moses of his divine identity. Let’s unpack this step by step, starting with how God addresses Moses as ‘my son’ in Moses 1:4, affirming his divine heritage. By contrast, Satan’s ‘son of man’ in verse 12 is a counterfeit, a way to diminish Moses to mere mortality, cutting him off from his connection to the divine.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, so you’re saying Satan is attacking Moses’s very sense of who he is? That’s chilling. How does this play out in the rest of the interaction?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, Sarah. Satan’s strategy is to confuse and degrade identity, to make Moses doubt his divine worth. But notice how Moses responds in verse 13: ‘Who art thou? For behold, I am a son of God, in the similitude of his Only Begotten.’ Moses reclaims his identity as a child of God, directly countering Satan’s lie. This sets up a pattern we’ll see across dispensations—identity is central to resisting temptation.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s powerful. So, are we seeing this just from Moses’s perspective, or does this identity struggle echo elsewhere in scripture? I’m curious how this looks through different lenses.

script.speaker: David
script.text: It absolutely echoes elsewhere. Let’s look at this from three angles: ancient Israel, the time of Christ, and our modern restoration. In ancient Israel, the children of Israel often forgot their covenant identity as God’s chosen people, leading to cycles of bondage and deliverance. Fast forward to Christ’s ministry, and we see Him affirming His identity as the Son of God, resisting Satan’s temptations in Matthew 4:1-11 with unwavering clarity.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And in our day? How does this connect to us now?

script.speaker: David
script.text: In the modern restoration, we have teachings like President Russell M. Nelson’s reminder in his 2022 devotional ‘Choices for Eternity,’ where he says, ‘The first thing [the Lord] would make sure you understand is your true identity.’ This mirrors what God did for Moses—affirming who we are as children of God shapes every choice we make. Notice this pattern: across all dispensations, knowing our divine identity is the foundation for resisting deception.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’m starting to see that thread weaving through time. Let’s dive deeper into this pattern of identity across dispensations. Where else do we see this in the scriptures we’re studying this week?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Let’s look at Abraham 3:22-23. Here, Abraham sees the premortal spirits and learns that they were ‘organized before the world was,’ and among them were ‘many of the noble and great ones.’ God tells Abraham, ‘Thou art one of them; thou wast chosen before thou wast born.’ This premortal identity affirms that we, like Abraham, have a divine origin and purpose long before our earthly experience.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So, it’s not just Moses getting this divine affirmation—it’s Abraham, and by extension, all of us. What’s the next stop on this pattern?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Let’s go to Moses 1:39, where God declares, ‘For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.’ Here, our identity as children of God is tied directly to His purpose—our eternal progression. This theme of divine identity and purpose runs from the premortal life in Abraham 3, through Moses’s calling, and into the modern teachings of the restored gospel.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s remarkable. It’s like a golden thread connecting us from before the world was to our ultimate destiny. But let’s ground this in some historical context. What do we know about the cultural backdrop that might make these identity affirmations even more striking?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great question. In the ancient Near Eastern context of Moses’s time, identity was often tied to tribal lineage or servitude to a king or deity. When God calls Moses ‘my son’ in Moses 1:4, it’s not just personal—it’s a radical redefinition against a culture where people saw themselves as subjects or slaves to earthly or false divine powers. Archaeological evidence, like inscriptions from that era, often shows people defining themselves by their allegiance to a ruler or idol, so God’s direct claim on Moses as His son would have been a profound shift.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s fascinating. So, this isn’t just a spiritual truth—it’s countercultural for Moses’s time. What’s another historical insight that brings this to life?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Another piece is the setting of divine encounters. In ancient traditions, including those preserved in texts like the Dead Sea Scrolls, mountains were often seen as places where heaven and earth meet, places of revelation. Moses’s vision in Moses 1, where he speaks with God ‘face to face’ as verse 2 describes, fits this cultural expectation but elevates it—God isn’t just a distant deity but a personal Father affirming Moses’s identity. This would have been both familiar and revolutionary to an ancient audience.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love how that context makes the story feel so immediate. Now, let’s circle back to that chilling moment with Satan’s words. How does understanding this identity piece resolve the mystery of why he called Moses ‘son of man’?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s where it gets powerful, Sarah. Satan’s use of ‘son of man’ in Moses 1:12 is a direct assault on the divine relationship God just established. By reducing Moses to a mere mortal, Satan is trying to sever that connection, to make Moses forget he’s been called ‘my son’ by God Himself. But Moses’s response in verse 13—‘I am a son of God’—is the ultimate rejection of that lie, showing that clinging to our true identity is our greatest defense.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s such a satisfying answer. It’s not just a word choice—it’s a battle over who Moses is at his core. Are there other connections in these chapters that most people might overlook?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely. One hidden connection is between Moses 1:6, where God tells Moses, ‘Thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten,’ and Abraham 3:24, where we learn that Christ was chosen in the premortal life to be the Redeemer. This links our identity as children of God to Christ’s role—our divine potential is tied to His atoning mission.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, so you’re saying our identity is connected to Christ’s identity?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Precisely. And here’s another connection: in Abraham 3:25, God says the purpose of earth life is to ‘prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.’ This echoes Moses 1:39, where God’s work is our eternal life. Both passages tie our premortal identity to the Plan of Salvation, showing that our journey here is part of a divine design leading to eternal progression.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s incredible. It’s like these chapters are a roadmap of who we are and where we’re going. How does this second connection deepen our understanding?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It shows that our identity isn’t just a static truth—it’s dynamic, tied to our choices and God’s plan. Notice how Abraham 3:25 emphasizes agency in the premortal council, and Moses 1:39 reveals God’s entire purpose is centered on us. This cross-reference highlights that our divine identity comes with responsibility and infinite potential, all made possible through Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I never saw that link before. It changes how I read both passages. Now, let’s think about how this applies to us today. How can understanding our identity as children of God shape our lives right now?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It’s transformative, Sarah. When we internalize that we are children of God, as Moses learned in Moses 1:4, it influences every decision, just as President Nelson taught in ‘Choices for Eternity.’ It means we approach challenges with the confidence that we have divine potential, and we resist temptations by remembering who we really are, much like Moses did in verse 13.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That feels so relevant. I’m thinking about moments when I’ve doubted myself, and realizing I’m a child of God could shift everything. What’s a practical way we can hold onto this truth day to day?

script.speaker: David
script.text: One way is to echo Moses’s response—affirm your identity regularly. When doubts or temptations come, say to yourself, ‘I am a child of God,’ just as Moses declared in Moses 1:13. Also, study teachings like Abraham 3:22-23 to remind yourself of your premortal nobility. These truths can anchor us in a world full of counterfeits.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a beautiful takeaway. Before we wrap up, David, what’s one final thought you’d like to leave with our listeners about these incredible chapters?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’d invite everyone to ponder Moses 1:39, where God reveals His work and glory is our eternal life. Let that sink in—your progression matters so deeply to Him. Take time to reflect on your divine identity and how it connects you to His plan across all dispensations, from premortal councils to today.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a powerful invitation. Thank you, David, for helping us uncover these profound truths. I’m walking away with a renewed sense of who I am and why I’m here. We hope you’ll join us again as we continue exploring the scriptures together.
